abstract: There are now three suspected cases in the city. The patients had recently been to China and came down with flulike symptoms.
headline: Coronavirus in New York: 2 More Possible Cases in City Are Identified
lead_paragraph: A day after New York City’s health authorities said that a woman was hospitalized with the city’s first suspected case of the new coronavirus, the authorities on Sunday announced that two more patients also might have the virus.

abstract: A two-week quarantine has left Masako Ishida and hundreds of others dealing with inconveniences and trying to figure out how to pass the time.
headline: Trapped on a Cruise Ship by the Coronavirus: When Is Breakfast?
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Hidden away in her cabin, Masako Ishida reckons she doesn’t face much risk from the coronavirus that has stalked her cruise ship, forcing an onboard quarantine of 3,700 passengers and crew members in the port city of Yokohama.

abstract: With infections doubling every four days and more than 600 deaths, China intensified its response in Wuhan, with house-to-house temperature checks and mass confinements at quarantine centers.
headline: China Tightens Wuhan Lockdown in ‘Wartime’ Battle With Coronavirus
lead_paragraph: WUHAN, China — The Chinese authorities resorted to increasingly extreme measures in Wuhan on Thursday to try to halt the spread of the deadly coronavirus, ordering house-to-house searches, rounding up the sick and warehousing them in enormous quarantine centers.

abstract: Dr. Li Wenliang issued a warning about a strange new virus. Then the authorities summoned him for questioning.
headline: Chinese Doctor, Silenced After Warning of Outbreak, Dies From Coronavirus
lead_paragraph: WUHAN, China —  He was the doctor who tried to sound a warning that a troubling cluster of viral infections in a Chinese province could grow out of control — and was then summoned for a middle-of-the-night reprimand over his candor.

abstract: A factory in western France has become an unlikely outpost to help overcome a severe shortage as supplies dry up in China.
headline: As Coronavirus Spreads, Face Mask Makers Go Into Overdrive
lead_paragraph: ANGERS, France — The relentless whir of machines echoing across a cavernous French factory floor this week is an unexpected result of the deadly virus that has nearly paralyzed cities in China and other parts of Asia. The company, Kolmi Hopen, happens to make an item that is suddenly one of the world’s hottest commodities: the medical face mask.

abstract: Evacuees taken to Australia’s Christmas Island, a former detention center for asylum seekers, have been given sunscreen, sandals and shorts. They also have video games.
headline: What It’s Like to Be Quarantined on an Island Over Coronavirus Fears
lead_paragraph: Life in an immigration detention center on Australia’s Christmas Island has not been as bad as David Huang feared. It is certainly a far cry from the conditions that thousands of asylum seekers have faced in the country’s offshore detention centers in recent years.

abstract: The doctor, Li Wenliang, had been silenced by the police after warning about the new coronavirus that has killed hundreds in China and sickened thousands.
headline: Widespread Outcry in China Over Death of Coronavirus Doctor
lead_paragraph: They posted videos of the Les Misérables song “Do You Hear the People Sing.” They invoked article No. 35 of China’s Constitution, which stipulates freedom of speech. They tweeted a phrase from “For Whom the Bell Tolls.”

abstract: The country is scrambling to prevent a larger outbreak even as it prepares for the Tokyo Olympics.
headline: Jump in Coronavirus Cases on Ship Poses a Critical Test for Japan
lead_paragraph: Japan already had several confirmed coronavirus cases when a giant cruise ship arrived at the port of Yokohama last week.

abstract: Xi Jinping has backed out of the spotlight as the country faces its worst crisis in years, reflecting the political risks he faces if efforts to contain the virus fail.
headline: Where’s Xi? China’s Leader Commands Coronavirus Fight From Safe Heights
lead_paragraph: WUHAN, China — President Xi Jinping strode onstage before an adoring audience in the Great Hall of the People in Beijing less than three weeks ago, trumpeting his successes in steering China through a tumultuous year and promising “landmark” progress in 2020.

abstract: The United States has no plans to conduct additional evacuations from China though some Americans are asking for help.
headline: First American Dies of Coronavirus, Raising Questions About U.S. Response
lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — A United States citizen died from the coronavirus in Wuhan, China, American officials said on Saturday. It was the first known American death from the illness, and was likely to add to diplomatic friction over Beijing’s response to the epidemic.

abstract: Germany and other countries were already vulnerable. The longer the Chinese economy remains crippled, the bigger the risk to the rest of the world.
headline: Coronavirus Shock Could Push Europe Into a Downturn
lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — So far, only scattered cases of the coronavirus have appeared in Europe, but the economic effects are proving harder to quarantine. The shock may be severe enough to push the vulnerable German economy, and perhaps the entire eurozone, into a recession.

abstract: China’s health authorities have decided to no longer count as confirmed cases those patients who test positive but don’t show symptoms. Skepticism was immediate.
headline: How Many Coronavirus Cases in China? Officials Tweak the Answer
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The news was abrupt and, to some, surprising: Overnight, a Chinese province near Russia, had cut its count of confirmed coronavirus cases by more than a dozen.

abstract: Confronting a viral epidemic with a scant supply of protective equipment, more than 1,700 Chinese medical workers have already been infected, and six have died.
headline: China’s Doctors, Fighting the Coronavirus, Beg for Masks
lead_paragraph: WUHAN, China — In the hospital where Yu Yajie works, nurses, doctors and other medical professionals fighting the new coronavirus have also been fighting dire shortages. They have used tape to patch up battered protective masks, repeatedly reused goggles meant for one-time use, and wrapped their shoes in plastic bags for lack of specialized coverings.

abstract: Chinese authorities are using infrared thermometers to screen people for the illness, as the devices have become synonymous with trying to contain deadly outbreaks.
headline: ‘Thermometer Guns’ on Coronavirus Front Lines Are ‘Notoriously Not Accurate’
lead_paragraph: It has become an iconic image of the coronavirus outbreak in China: a masked official aiming what appears to be a small white pistol at a traveler’s forehead.

abstract: When Kevin Tang’s American teacher found out he was stuck at home because of coronavirus, she decided to use music to improve his mood.
headline: Violin Lessons During the Coronavirus Outbreak. A Pupil’s Progress.
lead_paragraph: Thirty minutes into the violin lesson, Anthea Kreston knew that something was wrong.

abstract: Two video bloggers whose dispatches from the heart of the outbreak showed fear, grief and dissatisfaction with the government have gone silent.
headline: They Documented the Coronavirus Crisis in Wuhan. Then They Vanished.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The beige van squatted outside of a Wuhan hospital, its side and back doors ajar. Fang Bin, a local clothing salesman, peered inside as he walked past. He groaned: “So many dead.” He counted five, six, seven, eight body bags. “This is too many.”

abstract: Despite their high-tech tools, the authorities are mainly relying on a flood of workers to keep hundreds of millions of people from coming in contact with outsiders.
headline: To Tame Coronavirus, Mao-Style Social Control Blankets China
lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — China has flooded cities and villages with battalions of neighborhood busybodies, uniformed volunteers and Communist Party representatives to carry out one of the biggest social control campaigns in history.

abstract: Amid assurances that the Westerdam was disease free, hundreds of people disembarked in Cambodia and headed for airports. One was later found to be infected.
headline: Coronavirus Infection Found After Cruise Ship Passengers Disperse
lead_paragraph: The cruise ship had been shunned at port after port for fear it might carry the coronavirus, but when the Westerdam arrived in Cambodia on Thursday, the prime minister greeted its passengers with flowers.

abstract: Some factories are firing up again, but with many workers quarantined and parts in short supply, production is limited.
headline: Slowed by the Coronavirus, China Inc. Struggles to Reopen
lead_paragraph: Airbus is slowly restarting its assembly line in China. General Motors began limited production on Saturday. Toyota followed on Monday morning.

abstract: Scientists have dismissed suggestions that the Chinese government was behind the outbreak, but it’s the kind of tale that gains traction among those who see China as a threat.
headline: Senator Tom Cotton Repeats Fringe Theory of Coronavirus Origins
lead_paragraph: The rumor appeared shortly after the new coronavirus struck China and spread almost as quickly: that the outbreak now afflicting people around the world had been manufactured by the Chinese government.

abstract: The likely postponement of the most important spectacle on China’s political calendar reflects the Communist Party’s growing anxiety over the epidemic.
headline: Battling Coronavirus, China Signals Delay of Its Top Party Gathering
lead_paragraph: China signaled on Monday that it would postpone its most important political spectacle of the year, a sign of deepening anxiety within the ruling Communist Party about the threat posed by the coronavirus epidemic.

abstract: The family of Chloe Chang, a Taiwanese woman, is effectively trapped in Hubei Province, and in the middle of a spat between China and Taiwan.
headline: ‘Now We Are Refugees’: A Family in Limbo Amid the Coronavirus Outbreak
lead_paragraph: These days, Chloe Chang, a Taiwanese woman stranded at the center of China’s coronavirus outbreak, says she wakes up every half-hour during the night. Sometimes she breaks down in tears.

abstract: Xu Zhiyong, a prominent Chinese legal activist, went silent over the weekend. His girlfriend, Li Qiaochu, a social activist, has gone missing.
headline: China Detains Activist Who Accused Xi of Coronavirus Cover-Up
lead_paragraph: He portrayed China’s leader, Xi Jinping, as hungry for power. He accused Mr. Xi of trying to cover up the coronavirus outbreak in central China. In one of his most daring writings, he urged Mr. Xi to resign, saying, “You’re just not smart enough.”

abstract: The outbreak has exposed the powerlessness of private charities, civic groups and others who could help the effort but whom the Communist Party considers rivals.
headline: In Coronavirus Fight, China Sidelines an Ally: Its Own People
lead_paragraph: Hospitals in Wuhan and surrounding Hubei Province have been making urgent pleas to the Chinese people for three weeks as the new coronavirus ripples through the country: Send more protective gear.

abstract: At a small pharmacy in Hong Kong, part of the job has become calming nervous customers desperate for supplies.
headline: How a Pharmacy Handles Mask Hoarders and Coronavirus Fears
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — “It’s like World War III,” said May Tang, an employee at the Kit Pharm Dispensary Ltd. in Hong Kong.

abstract: The World Health Organization said China’s drastic limits on people’s movement had helped, but experts cautioned against predicting that the worst was over.
headline: Coronavirus Epidemic Keeps Growing, but Spread in China Slows
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Chinese officials hailed recent figures as evidence that the spread of the coronavirus epidemic has slowed, and World Health Organization officials said on Tuesday that China’s strict limits on its people’s movements have helped.

abstract: But if hard-liners in the U.S. administration were hoping for a united, anti-China message from Washington, that goal has been undermined by President Trump.
headline: Coronavirus Worsens U.S.-China Ties and Bolsters Hawks in Washington
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Tariffs and the trade war. Espionage and Huawei. Hong Kong, Taiwan and the South China Sea.

abstract: Some Chinese business figures are taking an unusual public stand, saying the containment efforts threaten to strangle the economy if applied too broadly.
headline: As China Fights the Coronavirus, Some Say It Has Gone Too Far
lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — China’s business leaders know better than to argue with Beijing. Leave the politics to the Communist Party, they long ago concluded, and the government will let them make money in peace.

abstract: The Everything Store, which stocks more than 100 million items, is working to avoid disruptions in its supply chain.
headline: Clicking Buy on Amazon? It’s Trying to Prevent a Coronavirus Caveat
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — What if the Everything Store couldn’t sell everything because of disruptions from the coronavirus?

abstract: As the country’s infection numbers soar, most cases have been connected to the Shincheonji Church of Jesus, which mainstream churches consider a cult.
headline: Shadowy Church Is at Center of Coronavirus Outbreak in South Korea
lead_paragraph: Read live updates on the coronavirus outbreak here.

abstract: A surge of risky borrowing by companies around the world leaves the global economy especially exposed to the potential costs of the outbreak.
headline: Coronavirus May Light Fuse on ‘Unexploded Bomb’ of Corporate Debt
lead_paragraph: LONDON — To grasp why the most important central banks — from the Fed to the Bank of England to the Bank of Japan — are now leaping into action as if the world were on fire, it helps to examine the subject of corporate debt.

abstract: Those with chronic health problems are more likely to develop severe illnesses and to die, research shows.
headline: Coronavirus Threatens Americans With Underlying Conditions
lead_paragraph: The new coronavirus is a serious threat to the elderly, as federal officials have been at pains to note recently. But they have stepped gingerly around advice for another group of Americans also at special risk from the infection: those with chronic health conditions.

abstract: Postponements and cancellations continued in an effort to curtail the spread of the virus.
headline: How the Coronavirus Is Disrupting Sports
lead_paragraph: Sports around the world continued to be disrupted, and even halted, by the spread of the coronavirus.

abstract: The N.B.A. suspends its season. Colleges move to distance learning. President Trump restricts travel from Europe. What are your thoughts on these and other recent developments?
headline: What Is Your Reaction to the Latest News About the Coronavirus Outbreak?
lead_paragraph: This week, the World Health Organization declared the coronavirus outbreak to be a pandemic. And in the past 48 hours, we have seen a dramatic turn of events in the United States affecting virtually all aspects of our lives, from our schools to the economy, from travel to the world of entertainment.

abstract: The president inaccurately described travel restrictions he had announced, falsely blamed his predecessor for testing shortages and misstated the role Google was playing in mitigating the outbreak.
headline: Trump’s False Claims About His Response to the Coronavirus
lead_paragraph: As he declared a national emergency over the coronavirus outbreak, President Trump attempted to deflect criticisms of his administration’s response to the virus with inaccurate claims. Here’s a fact-check.

abstract: Scientists are ramping up the breeding of lab mice as well as the testing of primates and other animals, but it all takes time.
headline: These Lab Animals Will Help Fight Coronavirus
lead_paragraph: Among the many lessons of the coronavirus pandemic is how close humans are to the rest of the animal kingdom. We get diseases from other animals, and then we use more animals to figure out how to stop the diseases. As research ramps up treatments and vaccines, animals are crucial to fighting the pandemic.

abstract: Federal officials are asking Americans for extraordinary vigilance against a new pathogen. President Trump has taken a different course, worrying scientists.
headline: Trump Is Tested for Coronavirus, and Experts Ask: What Took So Long?
lead_paragraph: After hosting a gathering with guests later found to be infected with the coronavirus, President Trump refrained from getting tested, let alone from self-quarantine, even as administration officials urged Americans to adopt stern new precautions.

abstract: Empty streets. Shuttered stores. Spain has joined the number of countries struggling to balance public health with freedoms especially prized in a relatively young democracy.
headline: Spain, on Lockdown, Weighs Liberties Against Containing Coronavirus
lead_paragraph: MADRID — The scene is becoming all too familiar, and now it has gripped Spain: Streets are empty, shops are shuttered, families are cloistered at home and the numbers of those infected with the coronavirus, and those who have died, are growing.

abstract: The hospitalizations sharpen fears that the nation’s front-line medical workers could be uniquely vulnerable, a health care organization said.
headline: Two Emergency Room Doctors Are in Critical Condition With Coronavirus
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Two emergency medicine doctors, in New Jersey and Washington State, are in critical condition as a result of coronavirus, reinforcing concerns that the nation’s front-line medical workers are becoming especially vulnerable to the virus, the American College of Emergency Physicians said.

abstract: The city’s West End theater district, Royal Opera House and other premier venues closed Monday after the prime minister warned patrons to avoid the theater during the outbreak.
headline: London’s Cultural Landmarks Shutter Amid Coronavirus Threat
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Last week, the lights went out on Broadway. On Monday, London’s West End — the last global theater stronghold to remain open through the growing coronavirus pandemic — went dark.

abstract: NYT Parenting readers shared their experiences.
headline: ‘You’re Already Worried’: Navigating Coronavirus While Pregnant
lead_paragraph: Brittany Dickey, 33, remembers breastfeeding in a mask.

abstract: The court said it would reschedule two weeks of arguments that had been set to start March 23, including major cases on President Trump’s financial records.
headline: Supreme Court Postpones Arguments Over Coronavirus
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court announced Monday that it would postpone its next argument session “in keeping with public health precautions.”

abstract: How the best- and worst-case scenarios compare with other common killers.
headline: Could Coronavirus Cause as Many Deaths as Cancer in the U.S.? Putting Estimates in Context
lead_paragraph: How the best- and worst-case scenarios compare with other common killers.

abstract: Experts offer advice on how to make the best possible decision for you and your family.
headline: Coronavirus Is Spreading. Should You Cancel Your Vacation?
lead_paragraph: With summer fast approaching, many families are wondering just how long coronavirus will remain at the center of our lives. The outbreak has sickened people worldwide and killed thousands, adding a new layer of anxiety when thinking about potential travel plans.

abstract: Lawmakers and policy experts say a paid-leave program that passed the House would still discourage some virus-stricken workers from staying home.
headline: Congress Is Knitting a Coronavirus Safety Net. It Already Has Big Holes.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In an effort to slow the spread of coronavirus and limit its damage to the economy, congressional leaders and President Trump are stitching together a new safety net for workers who contract the coronavirus or lose their jobs because of it.

abstract: Fears are growing about what happens if community transmission takes off in the crowded areas of the world’s second-most-populous nation.
headline: India Scrambles to Escape a Coronavirus Crisis. So Far, It’s Working.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Over the weekend in Lucknow, one of India’s bigger cities, young people packed into pubs. Despite the Indian government scrambling to lock things down, few on the bar scene were taking the coronavirus very seriously.

abstract: The delay in containment efforts could prove dangerous, particularly in nations where the health care system can’t handle a major outbreak.
headline: Having Brushed Off Coronavirus Threat, Southeast Asia Begins to Confront It
lead_paragraph: BANGKOK — For months, many Southeast Asian countries played down the threat posed by the new coronavirus. Some officials said that prayer would keep the disease away. Others expressed optimism that the tropical heat would slow the spread of the virus.

abstract: A psychologist offers tips tailored to age.
headline: How to Talk to Your Child About the Coronavirus
lead_paragraph: Not long after New York City schools closed down this week to help stop the spread of coronavirus, a colleague called to tell me about a troubling conversation she overheard on the street: A boy of about 8 asked his mother if he could have a play date with a friend. The mother responded, “OK, but I’ll only pencil it in. In case, you know, the world ends.”

abstract: The pandemic has clarified the dark bargain of our internet-connected devices: We look to them to protect our bodies and soothe our nerves, and in return, we hand over our minds.
headline: The Unending Anxiety of Coronavirus Content
lead_paragraph: This past weekend, as coronavirus radiated across the country and sent Americans scurrying into their homes, Rosanne Cash tweeted: “Just a reminder that when Shakespeare was quarantined because of the plague, he wrote King Lear.”

abstract: The pop music contest, which has brought high camp into European homes annually since 1956, says it will come back in 2021.
headline: Eurovision Song Contest Is Canceled Over Coronavirus Concerns
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The Eurovision Song Contest — Europe’s longest-running, most popular and perhaps its campiest talent competition — has been canceled because of the coronavirus pandemic.

abstract: The Times has compiled more than two dozen pieces of journalism in “Answers to Your Coronavirus Questions,” which is available to download for free.
headline: Free E-Book: Answers to Your Coronavirus Questions
lead_paragraph: Covid-19 cases continue to be confirmed. By following some basic steps, you can help reduce your risk and do your part to protect others.

abstract: Researchers calculated a 1.4 percent likelihood of dying in the city where the pandemic began. Earlier estimates ranged from 2 percent to 3.4 percent.
headline: Coronavirus Death Rate in Wuhan Is Lower than Previously Thought, Study Finds
lead_paragraph: A new study reports that people who became sick from the coronavirus in the Chinese city where the outbreak began likely had a lower death rate than previously thought.

abstract: Americans returning from Italy and Spain say border control officials didn’t screen them or tell them to isolate themselves.
headline: They Fled Coronavirus in Europe. Border Agents Asked if They’d Visited China or Iran.
lead_paragraph: When Pam Mundus and a friend landed in Milan for a weeklong vacation on Feb. 23, uniformed airport workers in face masks, attempting to contain the spread of the new coronavirus, took their temperatures.

abstract: Payton was tested on Monday after experiencing symptoms the day before.
headline: Saints Coach Sean Payton Is N.F.L.’s First Known Coronavirus Case
lead_paragraph: New Orleans Saints Coach Sean Payton is the first known member of the N.F.L. community to test positive for the coronavirus. Payton told ESPN on Thursday that his symptoms started on Sunday — the day after he attended the Rebel Stakes, a thoroughbred horse race at Oaklawn Park in Hot Springs, Ark. He said he was tested on Monday and received the results on Thursday.

abstract: The use of the existing drugs against the new virus is unproven, and some shortages have already been reported.
headline: With Minimal Evidence, Trump Asks F.D.A. to Study Malaria Drugs for Coronavirus
lead_paragraph: President Trump on Thursday exaggerated the potential of drugs available to treat the new coronavirus, including an experimental antiviral treatment and decades-old malaria remedies that hint of promise but so far show limited evidence of healing the sick.

abstract: The matriarch of the large New Jersey family died Wednesday night without ever knowing that her two oldest children had died before her.
headline: Coronavirus Ravages 7 Members of a Single Family, Killing 4
lead_paragraph: Grace Fusco — mother of 11, grandmother of 27 — would sit in the same pew at church each Sunday, surrounded by nearly a dozen members of her sprawling Italian-American family. Sunday dinners drew an even larger crowd to her home in central New Jersey.

abstract: The event was scheduled for May 12 through 23, but organizers said that could not happen. It might be shifted to June or July.
headline: Cannes Film Festival Postponed Over Coronavirus Concerns
lead_paragraph: The Cannes Film Festival has been postponed to reduce the spread of the coronavirus. The event, one of the world’s most important film festivals, was meant to run May 12-23, but organizers said in a statement on Thursday that could not happen.

abstract: Once the virus was here, his response shocked me.
headline: My Ex and I Fought About Everything. Then Came the Coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: Nearly two months ago, when the new coronavirus was upending life in China, I felt for those living through this nightmare. As the news became more and more dire, I began worrying about the virus making its way to the United States. I cycled through anxieties about illness and quarantine, but my biggest fear was how my soon-to-be-ex-husband and I would handle this.

abstract: Senate Republicans introduced a roughly $1 trillion economic stabilization plan that includes $1,200 payments to many taxpayers, tax cuts for large corporations and limits on paid leave.
headline: 5 Takeaways From the Coronavirus Economic Relief Package
lead_paragraph: UPDATE: Read our 5 takeaways on the $2 trillion stimulus that was passed.

abstract: Compare the number of deaths and the rate of increase over time in the places the virus has hit hardest so far.
headline: Coronavirus Deaths by U.S. State and Country Over Time: Daily Tracker
lead_paragraph: Compare the number of deaths and the rate of increase over time in the places the virus has hit hardest so far.

abstract: The ministers were unable to reach an agreement on issuing joint bonds, known as “corona-bonds.” Critics say their €540 billion loan package does too little for Spain and Italy.
headline: E.U. Officials Agree to Deal to Soften Coronavirus’s Economic Blow
lead_paragraph: This briefing has ended. Follow our live global coverage on the coronavirus epidemic.

abstract: Doctors, novelists and other writers are exploring, as quickly as they can, the pandemic’s impact on a country that was among its earliest victims.
headline: In Italy, Coronavirus Books Rush to Publication
lead_paragraph: MILAN — On Feb. 29, Paolo Giordano went to a dinner party in Rome. He didn’t shake hands or kiss anyone’s cheek, a serious breach in Italian etiquette.

abstract: Taking an experimental drug can be worse than taking nothing at all, warns Dr. Andre Kalil: “You are treating emotion.”
headline: At the Center of a Storm: The Search for a Proven Coronavirus Treatment
lead_paragraph: OMAHA — Beginning every morning at 5:30, Dr. Andre Kalil makes himself a double espresso, runs 10 kilometers, makes additional double espressos for himself and his wife, and heads to his office at the University of Nebraska Medical Center.

abstract: Migrant workers have not only been victims of Covid-19, but spreaders, too, creating a new world of risk for a vulnerable population.
headline: Coronavirus Finds Fuel in a World of Migrants
lead_paragraph: BANGKOK — His whole family back in Myanmar depended on him. But Ko Zaw Win Tun, one of an estimated four million migrant workers in Thailand, lost his job at a Bangkok toy store when the city went into a coronavirus lockdown.

abstract: The death came as Navy officials continued to struggle to combat the infection that has crippled the nuclear-powered Theodore Roosevelt, now docked in Guam.
headline: Sailor on Roosevelt, Whose Captain Pleaded for Help, Dies From Coronavirus
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A crew member from the aircraft carrier Theodore Roosevelt who had the novel coronavirus died on Monday, in a poignant punctuation to the plea from the ship’s captain two weeks ago for help from the Navy because “sailors don’t need to die.”

abstract: The Spanish soccer club pared back team activities well before authorities in Spain banned mass gatherings, and faced much criticism for it.
headline: Valencia Took Swift Action on Coronavirus, Then Took a Lot of Heat
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Anil Murthy had already been facing a barrage of criticism. But as a former diplomat for Singapore, Murthy, the president of Valencia, a top soccer team in Spain, was ready for most of the barbs directed his way for imposing restrictions on access to the club’s players.

abstract: New York deaths spike as the state releases a revised count, and California explores steps toward reopening. Trump announces his “opening the country” council.
headline: Coronavirus Updates: Trump Halts U.S. Funding of World Health Organization
lead_paragraph: This briefing has ended. Follow our latest coverage of the coronavirus epidemic.

abstract: The Miami police chief promised an investigation after a video showed Dr. Armen Henderson being handcuffed outside his home on Friday.
headline: Police Handcuff Black Doctor Who Tests Homeless for Coronavirus
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — The soundless video shows a man wearing a protective mask picking up bags and boxes outside a white van when a Miami police officer pulls up.

abstract: A network of health centers formed by the Soviet Union in the 1920s is providing expertise in quarantines and epidemic response for Covid-19.
headline: How Bubonic Plague Has Helped Russia Fight the Coronavirus
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — In a remote alpine meadow in Kyrgyzstan a few years ago, a teenage boy killed and skinned a marmot. Five days later, his parents carried the sweating, delirious boy to a village hospital where he died of bubonic plague.

abstract: As bleak a milestone in the pandemic as the new figures are, unconfirmed cases are believed to be far higher. More than 130,000 people have died from Covid-19.
headline: Worldwide Confirmed Coronavirus Cases Top 2 Million
lead_paragraph: The coronavirus pandemic passed 2 million confirmed infections and 130,000 deaths worldwide on Wednesday — bleak markers that experts say vastly understate the true spread and toll of the contagion because of a lack of testing.

abstract: Once-fringe ideas in economic theory are now nearly official policy as government borrowing surges and the Federal Reserve signals it could buy unlimited debt.
headline: How the Government Pulls Coronavirus Relief Money Out of Thin Air
lead_paragraph: The United States has responded to the economic havoc wrought by the coronavirus with the biggest relief package in its history: $2 trillion. It essentially replaces a few months of American economic activity with a flood of government money — every penny of it borrowed.

abstract: A New York City doctor on sending her children away while she treats patients in the U.S. epicenter of the pandemic.
headline: Fighting Coronavirus Means I Haven’t Seen My Kids for a Month
lead_paragraph: It’s been four weeks since I’ve seen my kids, and I’m starting to miss them.

abstract: Facing a global scramble for materials, British officials bought millions of unproven kits from China in a gamble that became an embarrassment.
headline: U.K. Paid $20 Million for New Coronavirus Tests. They Didn’t Work.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The two Chinese companies were offering a risky proposition: two million home test kits said to detect antibodies for the coronavirus for at least $20 million, take it or leave it.

abstract: Singapore reported a sharp increase in new infections, many of them among migrant laborers. At a long-term care home in Montreal, two nurses, 150 beds and 31 deaths.
headline: Britain’s Coronavirus Lockdown Is Extended, and Putin Postpones Military Parade
lead_paragraph: Read the latest developments in the coronavirus outbreak here.

abstract: No country is really sure how many people it has lost to the pandemic. But in Spain, it has become bitterly political.
headline: Counting Bodies and Pointing Fingers as Spain Tallies Coronavirus Dead
lead_paragraph: MADRID — Spain is recounting its dead.

abstract: The billionaire philanthropist is directing $37 million of the funds to programs to help at-risk populations in New York City.
headline: George Soros’s Foundation Pledges $130 Million in Coronavirus Relief
lead_paragraph: George Soros, the billionaire philanthropist and liberal financier, is directing more than $130 million through his foundation to combat the effects of the coronavirus, with $37 million aimed to help at-risk populations in New York City, including undocumented families and low-wage workers.

abstract: Nearly 150,000 people with the virus have died. A dispute over coronavirus measures in Sudan’s capital has prompted fears that the military would use a lockdown to seize power.
headline: W.H.O. Failed to Tell Syrian Kurds of Their First Coronavirus Death: Live Coverage
lead_paragraph: 新冠病毒疫情最新消息

abstract: Iran lifts Tehran’s lockdown. Hong Kong arrests pro-democracy figures even as it fights the virus.
headline: Germany Starts Broad Antibody Testing to Assess Spread of Coronavirus; Israel Relaxes Restrictions

abstract: Fallout from the agency’s failed rollout of national coronavirus kits two months ago continues to haunt U.S. efforts to combat the spread of the highly infectious virus.
headline: C.D.C. Labs Were Contaminated, Delaying Coronavirus Testing, Officials Say
lead_paragraph: Sloppy laboratory practices at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention caused contamination that rendered the nation’s first coronavirus tests ineffective, federal officials confirmed on Saturday.

abstract: The strictest lockdown measures in Europe have left countless children bored, exhausted and sometimes depressed.
headline: In Spain, a Call to ‘Free Our Children’ From Coronavirus Confinement
lead_paragraph: BARCELONA, Spain — For five weeks, Lia Aparicio Cenador hasn’t been outside once.

abstract: Buckingham Palace said the queen had also instructed that flags not be flown in her honor unless it was done while observing social distancing.
headline: Coronavirus Halts Another U.K. Ritual: Birthday Gun Salute for Queen
lead_paragraph: LONDON — When Queen Elizabeth II turns 94 on Tuesday, for the first time in her nearly seven-decade reign her birthday will not be marked by a gun salute — another longstanding ritual lost to the grim siege of the coronavirus.

abstract: The pandemic has reached Afghanistan’s presidential palace. Volunteers are stoking divisions as they tighten India’s lockdown.
headline: Chile to Issue Coronavirus ‘Immunity Cards’ to Those Who Recover
lead_paragraph: Volunteer virus patrol squads are popping up across India. Neighborhoods are imposing extra rules and sealing themselves off. In rural areas, some carry sticks, sickles and pockets full of nails for puncturing the tires of cars they deem suspicious.

abstract: Volunteers set up their own roadblocks. Neighborhoods set their own limits. The efforts could help the fractious country battle the outbreak but risk also stoking divisions and xenophobia.
headline: Powered by Fear, Indians Embrace Coronavirus Lockdown
lead_paragraph: BHOND, India — On the long, straight road into the farming village of Bhond, past fields of tomatoes, eggplant and rust-colored wheat, stood a police barricade, an incongruous sight for a settlement so small and remote.

abstract: An acclaimed young ensemble was making a fragile but sustainable living. Then the bottom dropped out.
headline: A String Quartet Is Crushed by the Coronavirus
lead_paragraph: Since its formation in 2008, the Tesla Quartet has been showered with critical accolades, released two recordings, hired a manager and lined up a full schedule at major concert halls around the world.

abstract: Lady Gaga, the Rolling Stones, Billie Eilish and more took over the major networks for a Global Citizen event celebrating essential workers and supporting the World Health Organization.
headline: Pop Music Faces the Coronavirus in Prime Time
lead_paragraph: Songs called for inspiration, empathy and perseverance on “One World: Together at Home,” the prime-time special produced by Global Citizen that was broadcast Saturday night on CBS, NBC and ABC and online. Stephen Colbert, Jimmy Fallon and Jimmy Kimmel, late-night representatives from each network, were the hosts, toggling awkwardly between deadpan comedy and earnestness. Lady Gaga helped select the musical lineup, which included Billie Eilish, Lizzo, Taylor Swift, Stevie Wonder, Paul McCartney, Camila Cabello and Shawn Mendes, the Rolling Stones, Elton John and more — many more, since there was also a six-hour webcast before the televised broadcast.

abstract: Unemployment has skyrocketed, but so has the size of the city’s volunteer pool and the number of people fostering animals. One month into the shutdown, the city is as complex as it ever was.
headline: 11 Numbers That Show How the Coronavirus Has Changed N.Y.C.
lead_paragraph: New York City has never looked so unlike itself. Deserted streets and vacant stores. Essential workers taking to lonely subways. Mandatory face coverings.

abstract: Istanbul recorded 2,100 more deaths over recent years between March and April, The Times found, suggesting a hidden toll.
headline: Istanbul Death Toll Hints Turkey Is Hiding a Wider Coronavirus Calamity
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — For weeks President Recep Tayyip Erdogan has presented Turkey’s performance in handling the coronavirus as one of the world’s most successful, as he maintained strict control over information about the outbreak.

abstract: Singapore, an early success story, is having a surge in cases, while European countries start to ease restrictions. Oil prices nosedived as a worldwide surplus grew.
headline: Coronavirus Death Toll Soars in Turkey; W.H.O. Warns of Vaccine Roadblock

abstract: A 60-day pause in immigration will not apply to guest workers. The Senate passed a $484 billion aid package.
headline: California Announces Early Coronavirus Deaths; Trump Narrows Immigration Ban
lead_paragraph: This briefing has ended. Read the latest developments in the coronavirus pandemic here.

abstract: In southern Italy, the pandemic is choking an already fragile economy. Protests erupt in Lebanon.
headline: Coronavirus World Updates: U.N. Warns World Hunger Could Double as Global Economy Crashes
lead_paragraph: In Italy, the pandemic hit the wealthy north first and hardest, but the poorer south is also suffering deeply, amid fears that things there could get much worse.
